Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Aging, Kinship, and Social Transformation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Population aging is an issue of rising global importance. Despite this, there are critical gaps in knowledge about what it means to grow old in low-income countries, where developing economies and multiple stressors can complicate formerly accepted models of aging. These lacunae in scholarship are problematic. They can result in overly simplistic understandings of older men and women's lives, the misdirection of scarce resources, and the undermining rather than reinforcing of local capacities. To address these problems, Yale University doctoral student, Aalyia Sadruddin, under the supervision of Dr. Catherine Panter-Brick, will undertake research in a particularly revealing lower-income context: post-conflict Rwanda. In Rwanda, as in other post-conflict situations, the oldest segments of the population must provide care for the youngest, the children that victims of the conflict left behind. In addition, the oldest segments are expected to lead the way in post-conflict reconciliation efforts while also bearing the effects of reduced government economic support. The additional levels of stress caused by this constellation of factors make the Rwandan case particularly revealing of the problems that the aging face, the strengths they bring to bear, and the limitations of their resilience. Lessons learned in Rwanda will be applicable throughout the world, including the United States.

The researcher will employ a mixed-methods approach and a comparative rural/urban design. In two carefully chosen sites, one rural and one urban, she will gather data using a variety of social scientific research methods, including: participant observation, semi-structured interviews, genealogical interviews, and textual discourse and media analysis. Findings from this research will broaden insights into the relationship between aging, family relations, and social change. Conclusions will advance social science theory of aging and help resolve debates on appropriate care, the role of kinship, and the capacity for social resilience in the developing world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Rwanda, rapid social and economic transformations in the aftermath of the 1994 genocide are complicating how people are aging from whom they receive care. Limited social science research on this issue has resulted in simplistic ideas about the salience and nature of care work for members of a generation whose kinship networks were ruptured during the genocide. Based on 20 months of multi-sited ethnographic research, my dissertation examines how ideologies and practices of care have shifted and are becoming renegotiated postgenocide. 

Specifically, I focus on how the elderly—who harbor complex memories of violence, loss, and shame—are knitting their lives back together through the practice of care. My research shows that caring for the elderly is not only about the everyday, micro, and intimate exchanges that take place between consanguineous kin members. Rather, it is a community driven practice that involves multiple actors—including the elderly themselves—who come together to reconcile a conflict-ridden past and reimagine a peaceful future. This is an important insight in Rwanda where the government has been critiqued for appropriating the concept of care in order to advance its “One People, One Nation” narrative of social and political transformation. As a result, by elaborating on the ways the elderly forge friendships, participate in community-based initiatives, and contribute to local society as promoters of peace, I interrogate the disjuncture between local and government conceptualizations of care and their connections to national identity and reconciliation processes. Such an approach opens up new avenues for theoretical discussion about care by arguing for more attention to be paid to intricate local knowledge and lived experiences rather than accepting institutionalized and universalized definitions.

Care is at the epicenter of global academic and policy debates as a result of population aging. As people age, the meanings they attach to care evolve. In Rwanda, care for the elderly involves a series of complex series of social, emotional, and physical tasks. Challenges aside, experiences of care are not solely defined by suffering. On the contrary, they emphasize the resilience of the elderly. Therefore, by looking at the diverse ways in which elderly Rwandans—members of the genocide generation—negotiate and practice care, my research reveals there is much more to the African human experience than suffering, chaos, and hopelessness: it shows that despite the legacy of a tumultuous past, dignity is cultivated, and hope created in Rwanda and across Africa.
